newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan chipmakers praise Samsung cut in chips.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan chipmakers praise Samsung cut in chips.

text.p: Taiwan computer chipmakers said on Thursday that Samsung Electronics' decision to cut production of 16-megabit memory chips may help stabilise the chips' recent freefalling prices but it would not have a lasting impact.
Analysts also said the South Korean company's output reduction may force its Taiwan competitors to speed up preparation for the industry's eventual entry into the next-generation 64 megabit market.

"We obviously welcome anything that would help stop the falling chip prices," said Chien Shueh-jen, vice president of Vanguard International Semiconductor. Vanguard is an affiliate of the island's biggest semiconductor maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.
Samsung is the world's largest producer of 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips (DRAMs), whose global prices have plunged about 80 percent in the past year.

But analysts in Taiwan said while Samsung's cutback may spell temporary relief for the dropping value of 16-megabit chips, it would not be a cure-all for the chips' underlying problem with oversupply.

"We don't expect DRAM prices to start a firm recovery until late this year (1997), when new computer products are expected to come out and demand for the chips will rise again," said Michael Hung, a securities manager for Nikko Securities.

Vanguard's Chien said Samsung's decision to cut 16-megabit chip production might indicate the South Korean giant would launch a campaign to push the global market towards the faster but more expensive 64-megabit chips.
"It was already inevitable that the 64MB chip would eventually take over the market; Samsung's move may just speed up the takeover," Chien said.
Vanguard said it aimed to attain production capability for the 64-megabit chips by 1998.

Joe Chiou, a securities analyst for Taiwan Securities Investment, said he did not expect the 16-megabit chip to become obsolete immediately after the arrival of the 64-megabit version, but profit yield for the lower-end DRAMs would slump.
"There will still be things like personal computers that would use the 16MB DRAMs, because personal computer users are not going to switch their chips that quickly," Chiou said.
"But still, the demand will be lower, meaning there is less profit to be made," he added.

Winbond Electronics Corp, Taiwan's third largest semiconductor maker, said it would not alter plans to begin producing both types of DRAMs by the end of 1997 under a technology agreement with Japan's Toshiba Corp.
"Right now the 16MB DRAMs are still the mainstream chip products in Taiwan. Samsung's decision will not influence our production plans," said Winbond spokesman Michael Liu.
But Winbond added it would closely monitor the market trend to determine how many of each DRAM type to make.
"If it becomes obvious that the 64MB chips are dominating the market, we would turn our production focus to them obviously," Liu said.
